1.b: Jr. Executives - white collar workers

areaDesc.8: This is a small rolling area, about 70% improved, and developed within the past few years of generally well constructed homes of uniform style and architecture. It has all utilities, is adequately served by gasoline bus transportation along Broadway with adequate schedule.     A good grade and junior high school is located just adjoining the northwest corner of the area. Community stores located along Broadway and are convenient. Properties surrounding the area, especially on the north, are much older and cheaper. Uniformity of style and construction, general appearance and maintenance of homes, type of population, and popularity of area as indicated by recent volume of new construction make this particular part a second grade area.

1.b: White-collar workers - Wage earners - Truck drivers

areaDesc.8: A level area of fairly uniformly constructed small cottage and bungalow type homes well maintained, just slightly less desirable than the better area adjoining on the north. It is only about 50% improved. Grade school located in area B-7 adjoining on north - stores located on Broadway - churches some distance away.     Nearest transportation is along Broadway to west and about 4 blocks north of the area and this is one adverse factor. Distance to center of city, lack of adequate transportation and lack of building restrictions make this a third grade area.

1.b: Business and professional men - executives

areaDesc.8: This area known as "Lindbergh Forrest" and the subdivision was started about 10 years ago by a speculative builder. It is only about 25% improved, is well laid out in a wooded section, with rolling terrain. Construction is generally good and of uniform style and architecture. Has all utilities but publc sewerage. Area has no public transportation and this has some adverse effect. It is only a short distance from the principal business center but is across the Tennessee River. Schools are fairly convenient and community stores are located only a short distance away.     The area is not developed for about 1 block from the Highway although the subdivision extends up to the Highway. On the western side of the highway is shown a red area but the two areas are divided by the four lane highway and land on either side of the highway is only sparsely improved with a few good homes and several filling stations.

1.b: Wage earners in lower income bracket

areaDesc.8: This is a small area made up largely of rather cheaply constructed small houses. It is rolling and only about 50% improved. Some better homes are located along Sutherland Avenue, but only a few of them. Distance to stores, schools and transportation are detrimental factors. Chief approach to principal business center is through a fourth grade area.     Airport adjoining on East has practically been abandoned since construction of new airport and is now being used by the National Guard.     Distance to city, lack of adequate transportation, distance to schools and cheaper construction make this a third grade area.

1.b: Low-rage earners - WPA workers

areaDesc.8: A small level area about 20% improved with cheap small houses poorly maintained. It is between 2 good areas to east and west but this area is vacant on both sides where the better areas are located which affords protection to the better adjoining areas.     It has all utilities but public sewerage and lacks transportation facilities. Very little likelihood of further cheap construction is this spot and possible the future may see an improvement in the area.     Stores just south of area but some distance to schools and churches. Distance to center of city is an adverse factor.

1.b: Negro domestics and cheap laborers

areaDesc.8: This is just a small area of shacks occupied by Negroes. It is rolling to hilly, about 40% improved. Has all utilities and transportation is by gasoline bus along broadway. Houses are cheaply built and poorly maintained and there is nothing in the area to recommend it. Because of cheap rent and easy access to transportation no difficulty is experienced in keeping the habitable houses occupied.

1.b: Factory workers - mechanics

areaDesc.8: This is a small area, slightly rolling, about 25% improved and lying on the edge of the city limits. Streets are macadam and no sidewalks. Part inside city limits has all utilities and that outside has all except public sewerage. New construction has all been on Sanderson Road, a new street cut through at the western side of the area. Grade school is located in area. Nearest transportation is about one mile distant. Several small industrial plants located on Texas and some residents of the area are employed there. Community store at Northeast corner of area, but it is quite some distance to principal business center. Cemetary adjoins on east. Excepting Sanderson Road, all of area consists of scattered small homes of cheaper construction, cottage and bungalow type, about 20 years old.     Type of construction, age of majority of improvements, distance from center of city and lack of adequate transportation make this a third grade area.

1.b: Business & professional men - executives - white collar workers

areaDesc.8: This is a small area, rolling to hilly, and about 98% improved. the best part is located on Clinch and White west of 19th Street. The eastern part is the older and is subject to encroachment of rooming and boarding houses for students of the University of Tennessee and Fraternity Houses.     There are a great many four family brick apartments on Laurel Avenue and several larger apartments scattered throughout the area of the better type.     Western part of area contains most of the single-family homes which are generally well constructed of uniform style and architecture. Grade school in area C-4 to the east. Area is within walking distance of principal business center, had adequate transportation by gasoline bus and street car, and is convenient to stores located on Cumberland Avenue. Has all utilities.     Fort Sanders Hospital, a private institution, is located at corner of Clinch and 17th Streets.

1.b: Jr. Executives - busienss & professional men - white collar workers

areaDesc.8: This is a small area along Fairmont Boulevard and Emoriland Boulevard, consisting of small single-family homes, generally well constructed of uniform style and architecture. The name of Aviation Avenue (extension of Fairmont) has been changed to Fairmont Boulevard and has been continued eastward for about three blocks beyond the city limits and the major portion of new building in the area within past year has been done on Fairmont outside city limits.     Portion inside city has all utilities and outside has all but public sewerage. School is located on Emoriland Boulevard, transportation is by gasoline bus along Broadway with adequate schedules, but eastern part of area is some distance from transportation.     Stores along Broadway and convenient.     It is a good second class area of medium priced homes, well maintained and occupied by a substantial type of people.

1.b: Junior executives - white collar workers

areaDesc.8: This area is known as "Indian Hills". It is a beautifully wooded section with rolling terrain and is about 50% improved. Homes are of uniform stlye and architecture for rather cheap construction, and for this reason there is some sales resistance. Lot values have also suffered a severe decline during recent years.     Grade school is within walking distance and community stores are not far distant. Transportation is by gasoline bus along Washington Pike (North boundary) which connects with bus along Broadway. Distance from center of city adversely affects. Part of area inside city limits has all utilities and part outside has all but public sewerage.     Most new construction has been at northwest corner and on the eastern side of area. It is what might be termed a low second grade area.

1.b: Factory workers in woolen mills - Foundry - Sangravel Material Company

areaDesc.8: This is a rolling area along the banks of the Tennessee River, only about 40% improved. A textile plant, sangravel plant and a marble plant are located in the area and some residents in the area are employed in these plants. There are some better type of houses located at Blount and Hawthorne. Some small stores located in the area but some distance to schools and churches. Only transportation is by gasoline bus along the highway which is the eastern boundary, but it is only a short distance from the area to the principal business center which lies just across the river.     Poor maintenance of improvements, cheap construction, unstable type of predominating population make this a fourth grade area.

1.b: Laundry - Packing plant - Marble workers

areaDesc.8: This is the oldest section in South Knoxville - a rolling to hilly area about 80% improved. Sevier Avenue is almost entirely business out to Claude Street and several industrial plants are located north of Sevier, between it and the river - a large lumber and millwork plant, packing plant, laundry and others. Some nice homes of a much better type than the average for the community are located on Phillips between Agee and Daisy. School is located in area, also stores and churches. Not far distant to principal business center. Gasoline bus transportation along Sevier Avenue.     It is a fairly good area, but age of properties, antiquity of architecture, lack of uniform type of improvements make it a fourth grade area.

1.b: White collar worker - minor executives

areaDesc.8: This area located in Fountain City, an unincorporated village, and free from Knoxville city taxes. Terrain is rolling, area about 65% improved. Grade school just across Jacksboro Pike in adjoining area and large county high school is located in area C-8, within walking distance. Fountain City business center not far distant.     Transportation is by gasoline bus along Jacksboro Pike with adequate schedule. Has all utilities except public sewerage.     Better part of the area (the 40%) is located south of Sanders Lane, and the lower priced part (the 60% part) is located in the northern part. Properties along Gibbs and Hillcrest are the older ones (about 15-20 years) and the major portion of the part south of Hillcrest has been built up within past 5 years.     It is a good area of moderate priced bungalow type homes, fairly well constructed of uniform style and architecture and occupied by a substantial type of people of moderate incomes. Volume of new construction during past two years is indicative of popularity of area.

1.b: Marble plants - Bakery - Other industrial workers

areaDesc.8: This is a rolling to hilly area containing many different types of houses in a section known as "Vestal". It is about 50% improved but predominantly of cheaper type of construction. The southwestern part of the area along Avenue A, B, C and D contains small cheaply constructed houses, 3 and 4 rooms, ranging about $800 to $1200. A small area around Immanuel and Petway is much better, and the same is true of a small area on Goode just off Blount. School and stores located in area, and Young High School, a county school, is not far distant.     Some sections of the area have some very nice homes in it, but the predominating type is of cheap construction, not well maintained and the general characteristics of the community make it a fourth grade area.

1.b: Marble workers - Factory workers - Clerical - Wage earners

areaDesc.8: This is a rolling area located in South Knoxville. Better properties are located on Young Avenue and several homes on this street about 30% higher in value than average for the area. City limits line runs along Young Avenue for a short distance and Young High School (a county high school) is located just outside city limits. Grade school located in area. Children of city residents can attend county high school without paying tuition.     Part of area along state highway is almost entirely vacant - a few scattered rather nice homes and several filling stations being located on it. It is a main traffic artery out of the city to the south and carries a heavy traffic load. There has been some activity in new construction in this area but in the cheaper bracket. Area to the west, cheap construction and location south of the river makes this a third grade area.

1.b: Business & professional men, white collar workers

areaDesc.8: This area is known as "Forrest Hills". The part south of Sutherland Avenue, especially on Chambliss, contains the cheaper properties and this part is level to gently rolling, about 80% improved with homes fairly well constructed of uniform style and architecture. Forrest Hills Drive in this part of the area has some better, more expensive homes.     The part north of Sutherland Avenue is only about 20% improved and is very rolling to hilly. The higher priced homes are located in this part of the area and most of new construction in last year has been in this part. It is outside city limits and has all utilities except public sewerage. Part South of Sutherland Avenue is inside city limits and has all utilities.     It is some distance to schools and transportation and this is one adverse influence.     Stores are located on Dixie Highway just south of the area.     Recent volume of new construction is indicative of popularity of area.

1.b: White collar workers

areaDesc.8: This is a small, level area, about 95% improved, built within past 3 years. It is well laid out, contains about 40 homes, fairly well constructed of uniform style and architecture.     It was developed by a building contractor with a reputation for good construction and he has had little difficulty in disposing of these homes.     Distance to transportation and schools has some slight adverse effect. Cemetary adjoins on north and to south is one of main highways leading from city and lined with beer taverns, sandwich shops and filling stations.     It is outside city limits and has all utilities except public sewerage.     It could hardly be termed a high second grade, but the fact that it is new, high percentage of home ownership, and its uniform construction makes it a desirable place in which to live.

1.b: Low-wage group - WPA workers - Common laborers

areaDesc.8: This is a small area about 70% improved. In the west end of the area, on Sutherland, about 10 houses have been built within past 3 or 4 years which are of much better grade than remainder of area, which is composed of a mixture of shacks and cottages of cheap construction. Grade school and small store in area. Transportation is by gasoline bus along Sutherland. Southern part of area between railroad and first grade area on south is on the side of a hill and immediately on going over the crest of the hill the first grade section along Kingston Pike is reached. Along the creek running through the southern part of the area there is no development and that on the hillside towards the first grade area to the south is sparse and of rather cheap construction. Small public park is located adjoining eastern side of area between it and railroad tracks.     Marble works located along railroad track just east of area.

1.b: White collar workers - professional men - executives

3.3: Practically all built for lot owners for homes

areaDesc.8: A gently rolling, well wooded area about 30% improved with homes of uniform style and architecture and well constructed. Has all utilities but public sewerage, each house having septic tank. Bus transportation along Tazewell Road and Jacksboro Pike with adequate schedule. Grade school in area and county high school not far distant. Community business center located at junction of Tazewell Road and Jacksboro Pike.     It is located outside city limits, in Fountain City, an unincorporated village, and is free from Knoxville city taxes. Cemetary is located just across Tazewell Road at southeast corner of area.     Lots are large, improvements are uniform in style and architecture and are well maintained, population is of the substantial type and popularity of the area is indicated by the volume of now construction in past two years.     Jump in grade, from first to third for area just south, is explained by the fact that there is a strip of vacant territory about 2 blocks wide between the two areas and the property fronting on Tazewell Road is adversely affected by encroaching business, filling stations, etc.

1.b: Business and professional men - executives

areaDesc.8: The area contains the highest priced residences in the city. It is rolling to hilly, beautifully wooded and is about 20% improved. When first opened, about twelve years ago, lot values were very high ranging from about $40 to $100 per front foot, but these prices have greatly declined and range now from about $15 to $40 per front foot. Along Kingston Pike and Cherokee Boulevard are the expensive homes, with the more moderate priced homes located in the central portion of the area.

1.b: R.R. shop workers, mechanics, common laborers, and all types of low-wage earners

areaDesc.8: An area with a mixture of most every type of cheap house with some few scattered better properties located on Minnesota at Heiskall and in the western end of the area west of Glenn Avenue between Old Paper Mill Road and Keith. In the center of the area along Tennessee Avenue, and along the eastern side are located many industrial plants. Area is about 50% improved but improvements on the whole are cheap and not well maintained. City dump is located just off Baxter at corner of McSpadden. Southern Railway Company has large shops at northeast corner of area and formerly employed hundreds of men many of whom lived in the area near the shops, but about 12 years ago the main shops were moved to John Sevier, about 15 miles distant, which took the greater number of these employees away and has resulted in a great decline in this part of area. Several smaller industrial plants in the area have also been abandoned. A low-cost housing project for white people "Western Heights" is now being built in the area at the junction of Jourolman and Virginia. It will provide 244 new units, will cost about $1,256,575 and will rent for approximately $3.00 per room per month. It will be ready for occupancy about May 1940. Area is well served by schools and stores. Transportation is by gasoline bus and is adequate.

1.b: Negro school teachers - Mechanics - Common laborers - Domestics - All types of Negro workers

areaDesc.8: This area is almost entirely occupied by Negroes. It is rolling and about 90% improved. Is within walking distance of principal business center and has all utilities. It contains a conglomeration of small shacks and cottages of varying degrees of repair. In the northern part is located Knoxville College, a Negro college, and some very fair properties are located around it occupied by some of the faculty members of the college. A low-cost housing project for Negroes "College Homes" is now being built just south of the college. It will be completed about June 1940 and will provide about 320 units. Rental will be about $3.00 per room per month. At the south end of the area several industrial plants are located. Some white people live in the southeast corner of the area along Deaderick Street and others but Negroes are gradually getting into this section. In the extreme southeast tip of the area along Main Street and south of it are some large older properties occupied by white people ranging in value from $2500 to $4000, quite a bit in excess of the average of the remainder of the area, but these properties are old and largely used for rooming and boarding houses.

1.e: Some infiltration of lower-income group in northern part of area
1.b: White-collar workers - Some industrial workers

areaDesc.8: This is a rolling area, almost 100% improved, within walking distance of principal business center of city, schools, churches and community stores are convenient. The Eastern part of area is very close to main campus of University of Tennessee, it contains many large old homes formerly occupied by wealthy citizens but in recent years have been turned into rooming houses for university students and fraternity houses. The Northern part of the area is near industrial plants located along the railroad tracks just North of the area and some residents in this section work in these plants. The Western part of the area is the more recently improved but construction is somewhat cheap.     Part of area along Cumberland is interspersed with stores, filling stations and other small business establishments.     Age of properties, surrounding influences on north, west and east make this definitely a third grade area.

1.b: White-collar workers - Some industrial workers

areaDesc.8: This is a rolling area about 80% improved. It is within walking distance of principal business center and also well served by street car and bus transportation. School is located in area, churches and stores very convenient. The Eastern side of the area adjoins the main campus of University of Tennessee, consists mostly of large old homes some of which are fraternity houses and some are used as boarding and rooming houses for university students.     Circle Park, in southeastern corner, is best section of area and contains large, old homes occupied by wealthy citizens, but there are only about a dozen houses in this section and surrounding influences are against it. Western side of area is the more recently improved but construction is somewhat cheap. Railroad track is western boundary and plant of Fulton Sylphon Manufacturing Company is located just accross the track from this area. Some residents of the area work in this plant.     Age of properties, surroundings, type of construction make this a third grade area.

1.b: Business & professional men - executives

areaDesc.8: This is a rolling area about 98% improved. It has all utilities, is within walking distance of principal business center and well served by street car. Along 17th Street, between Yale and Rose are located several large, expensive homes occupied by some wealthy citizens. The other higher priced properties are located on Lake Avenue, Terrace Avenue, Caledonia and Melrose. Cheaper properties are located on Yale, Lilly and Rose.     Eastern part of area is subject to encroachment of rooming and boarding houses for students of the University of Tennessee, and Fraternity Houses. Schools, stores and churches are covnenient and area is a very popular residential section.     Type of improvements, type of population and easy accessibility of center of city will keep this section desirable for many years.

1.b: Negro laborers - Domestics - Low-wage earners

areaDesc.8: Just a small area of cheap properties occupied by Negroes in a section lying along the river and railroad tracks and back of the University of Tennessee. It is very hilly, about 80% improved with cheap properties. It is occupied largely by Negro laborers and domestics. White people live in the western end of the area. Type of property, population, lack of maintenance and location make it a fourth grade area.

1.b: Small salaried clerical workers - Mechanics - Wage earners

areaDesc.8: This area located in South Knoxville, is rolling to hilly and only about 40% improved. Some very nice large homes on Highland Avenue (northern part) - remainder of area consists of small 5-6 room cottage and bungalow type in the cheaper bracket. New school located in area and some small stores also, but some distance to churches and community business center. The part of the area outside city limits have been developed within past 5 years, consists of about 100 houses of fairly uniform construction and well maintained - about 20 new houses built in this section in past year.     Distance to center of city, location on south side of river, and majority of improvements being in cheaper bracket make this a third grade area.

1.b: Business men - Jr. executives, white collar workers

areaDesc.8: This area is known as "Island Home" and is level, about 80% improved. It is a well laid out subdivision, of generally well constructed homes of uniform style and architecture. The area suffers from proximity to Tennessee River, also bad approach through area D-10.     Nearest grade school is located is area D-10 and this is also an objectionable feature - distance to high school is another objection. Area has all utilities and adequate transportation. State School for Deaf adjoins area on southeast. Objectionable feautres cited and the fact that it is located south of the River make the area a "light blue" area.

1.b: Clerical workers - Wage earners

areaDesc.8: A small rolling to hilly area, about 30% developed, located at the edge of the city limits. No sidewalks. School, church and store convenient.     Gilbert Lane is the best street - others contain cheaper properties fairly well maintained. Transportation by gasoline bus at about 3 blocks from northwest corner.     Distance to center of city, lack of restrictions and uniformly, and predominating cheaper construction make this a third grade area.

1.b: Industrial workers in furniture factories and Southern Railway Shops.

3.3: Built by lot owners for homes

areaDesc.8: This is an area of fairly uniform constructed cheaper homes, many occupied by industrial workers employed in C.B. Atkin Company furniture manufacturers, located at north end of area, and in Southern Railway Shops, located just a short distance west of the area. It is fairly level and about 85% improved. School is located in area. School is located in area and churches and stores are convenient. Transportation is by gasoline bus along Central Avenue.     In southern part of area along Harvey Street are some very cheap shotgun type of houses. Age of properties, lack of proper maintenance, mixed type of style and construction make this a third grade area.

1.b: Factory workers - clerical workers - Wage earners

areaDesc.8: A level to rolling area about 98% improved - greater portion consisting of small 5-6 room cottage and bungalow type houses averaging about 30 years of age. Grade and high school located in area - it is within walking distance of principal business center. On glenwood between Luttrell and Scott there are some large old expensive homes formerly occupied by wealthy families but now being turned into small apartments.     Age of properties, antiquity of architecture, completeness of development and infiltration of lower income group make this a third grade area.

1.b: Negro laborers - Low-wage earners - Some Negro professional men - Some white mechanics and clerical workers.

areaDesc.8: This is one of the oldest sections of the city - a rolling to hilly area the western side of which is occupied almost exclusively by Negroes. There is almost every type of house, shacks, cottages and large old 2-story houses, all poorly maintained. It adjoins the principal business center of the city on the west which makes it a popular living place for the poor type of population.     Along Hill and Rouser streets there are white people living and homes are well maintained, of much better type of construction than remainder of area, with values ranging from $2000 to $3500 and renting from $20 to $35 per month. The same condition exists along Main Street to Swan Street except properties are not as well maintained and values not as high.     Better type of Negro population lives on Dandridge, Vine and Bethel. A large Negro high school is located in the area. A low-cost housing project. "Austin Homes" for Negroes is to be built on Preston at Vine Street. It will contain 200 units when completed and will cost $839,000. Property has been bought and contract is to be let about middle of December. Construction will take about 12 months from time it is started. 57 units are to be demolished on this site. At Preston and McCallie there are located several large tobacco warehouses which extend south on Preston Street for about two blocks.

1.e: Infiltration of Negroes and lower-income group
1.b: White-collar workers - Some businessmen

areaDesc.8: This area located on a high hill overlooking the Tennessee River and has some very nice homes in it. However, the approach to the area is through a Negro section of very old, dilapidated properties and Negroes and lower income group are gradually getting into this area.     Eastern side contains the cheaper properties and is sparsely improved - as a whole area about 40% improved. Western part contains better properties but surroundings make this a third grade area.     Some distance to white schools and churches.

1.b: White-collar workers - some factory workers of Standard Knitting Mills

areaDesc.8: A level to rolling area about 85% improved. One of the largest textile plants in city from standpoint of number of employees is located in area just north and many of these employees reside in this area.     Better part of area is Fifth, Magnolia and Linden. Cheaper properties in northern stores located in area. Transportation by electric street car and is adequate. Grade school and Junior High School located in area.     Age and type of properties, completeness of development and obsolete type of construction make this a third grade area.

1.e: Gradual infiltration of slightly lower income population
1.b: Business & professional men - white collar workers

areaDesc.8: Remaining 5% consists of apartments, 4 to 32 units, 3/5 units, brick, average age about 12 years, renting from $35 to $60 per month and valued at about $7500 to $40,000. No sale demand for them but rental demand is good.     This is a rolling area about 80% improved, the vacant part being at the northeast corner, remainder about 100% improved. Magnolia Avenue has many large homes that were very expensive when built, it is a wide street and one of the principal arteries leading from the city to the east and carries a heavy traffic. Most all new construction has been on Woodbine and has been by a speculative builder. Transportation facilities are excellent, churches, schools and community stores convenient. Land values were originally very high in this area, $35 to $70 per front foot, and the section is now competing with comparable section having lot values from $10 to $25 per front foot. It will remain a popular rental area for many years because of its accessibility to principal business center, but because of fading home ownership it can hardly be classed above a "light blue" area.

1.b: Mechanics - Wage earners - Clerical workers

areaDesc.8: A level to rolling area consisting largely of small 5-6 room cottage and bungalow type houses, fairly well maintained but of cheaper construction. Amusement Park located on north side of area.     Eastern part is known as "Burlington" and a community business center of some size of area along Abner Street is a small section of very cheap 3-4 room houses that should be classed fourth grade but it is only a very small section. Southern part of area is sparsely developed.     Lack of uniformity of construction, age of properties and cheaper improvements make this a third grade area.     Grade school in area, churches convenient, transportation by electric street car along Magnolia.

1.b: Business and professional men - executives

3.3: Mostly built by owners of lots for homes

areaDesc.8: The part of this area north of Holston Drive is known as Chilhowee Hills and the part south of Holston Drive is known as Holston Hills. The Chilhowee Hills part is more thickly improved with homes ranging from about $5000 to $7500, well constructed of uniform style and architecture, well maintained - and the Holston Hills part contains the larger, more expensive homes with the larger lots, but is more sparsely improved. The Holston Hills part adjoins the Holston Hills Country Club and Golf Course. The entire area is about 25% improved.     Area is outside city limits - has all utilities except public sewerage. County grade school is located just across the highway north of the area. Nearest transportation is gasoline bus which stops at city limits and does not reach this area.     Largest volume of new construction within past two years has been in the range from $6000 to $8000. Type of improvements, type of population, makes this a first grade area.

This is a rather large area but properties are fairly uniform in style throughout the area. It is rolling to hilly, about 60% improved. Schools are located on both east and west side of area and are convenient to entire area. Transportation is by gasoline bus along Broadway with shuttle bus along Washington Avenue through southeastern part. Broadway is a wide thoroughfare, the main artery to Fountain City and carries a heavy load of traffic. It is dotted with stores, filling stations, sandwich shops, tourist homes, some nice private homes and two nice large apartment houses.     The northeast corner, the eastern side between areas B-7 and B-9, and the western side beyond area B-8 are sparsely developed. It is an area of spotted improvements, some good, some bad and some indifferent. As a whole properties are fairly well maintained. Distance to principal busienss center is one adverse factor especially to the eastern and northeastern parts of the area.     Most new construction is in eastern and southeastern parts and it is likewise spotted.

1.b: Factory workers - Laborers - Domestics

areaDesc.8: This is a rolling area located at the edge of city development. Population in northeast corner is almost entirely Negro. Several lumber mills and a textile mill are located on the railroad tracks running through the center of the area and provide employment for many residents in the area.     Best part of the area is 4 blocks on the west and of Cecil Avenue, the northern boundary of the area. Houses in these 4 blocks are 5-6 room bungalow type valued at about $2000 to $3000 and renting at from $18 to $25 per month. The remainder of the area consists of small shacks and cottages, poorly maintained and cheaply constructed. Small stores in community but some distance to schools. Western end is served by gasoline bus on Broadway but eastern end lacks adequate transportation facilities.

1.b: White collar workers - some junior executives

3.3: Readily - largely built for lot owners

areaDesc.8: Located in Fountain City, an unincorporated village, and free from Knoxville City taxes. Terrain is rolling, area about 40% improved with medium priced bungalow type homes, well maintained and fairly uniform as to style and architecture. Transportation is by gasoline bus along Broadway with adequate schedule - with western part of area somewhat distant from transportation. Grade school and large county high school located in Area C-3 adjoining, and are within walking distance. Business center is also convenient.     It is an area of good, medium priced homes occupied by a substantial type of people with moderate incomes. It is far enough away from Knoxville to be free from the smoke of the city and yet only 20 minutes automobile time from the main business center of Knoxville and about thirty minutes by bus transportation. Area has all utilities except public sewerage.

1.b: White-collar workers - Businessmen

3.3: Built for lot owners for homes

areaDesc.8: This area contains the older part of Fountain City, is rolling to hilly and about 75% improved. The business part of Fountain City is located about in the center of the area. Improvements vary from small cottages to large two-story house of frame construction, old but fairly well-maintained. The population is of substantial type.     Grade and county high school are located in area. Transportation to Knoxville is by gasoline bus along Broadway with adequate schedule. Area has all utilities excepting public sewerage, homes having septic tanks.     Southern strip of area along Broadway is dotted with filling stations, beer taverns, soft drink stands and sandwich shops, with some fairly substantial homes. Properties are fairly well constructed on the average but are old and lack uniformity of type and architecture.

1.b: Low income wage earners of various kinds

areaDesc.8: This is an area about 25% improved, lying outside city limits. Terrain is rolling. Improvements are of very cheap construction and maintenance is only fair. Has all utilities except public sewerage and some of the homes have outside toilets - others septic tanks.     Along Tazewell Road on the north side of the area are several stores, filling stations, etc., and the few homes located on this Road are much better than those in the southern part of the area. Cemetary is located adjoining on the east by apparently does not adversely affect this area.     Transportation is by gasoline bus along Tazewell Road and Jacksboro Pike and Schedules are Adequate. Grade school located in adjoining areas to north and large county high school in area C-8, within walking distance.     Cheap construction, unfavorable appearance and type of population make this a third grade area.

1.b: Business and professional men and executives

3.3: Built for lot owners as homes

areaDesc.8: A new subdivision with large, well wooded lots gently rolling terrain, known as "Harrill Hills", about 25% improved. Improvements are uniform in style and architecture and well constructed. Subdivision is well laid out and has charm and appeal.     It is located in Fountain City, an unincorporated village, free from Knoxville city taxes. Has all utilities except public sewerage, each house having its septic tank. Transportation is by gasoline bus along Jacksboro Pike and schedule is adequate. No school in area but both grade and high school in walking distance. Fountain City business center not far distant.     Population is substantial, style and construction uniform and popularity of the area is indicated by volume of new construction in past two years.

1.b: Factory workers - Clerical

areaDesc.8: An area at the edge of the northern city limit line which runs into the edge of a high hill (could be termed a small mountain). Western part about 50% improved with 4-6 room cottage type houses and a scattering of slightly better type of bungalow. Several industrial plants are located along western and southern boundary along railroad tracks. Eastern end has railroad track through it, very sparsely improved and little likelihood of further improvement because of lack of outlet across railroad tracks to Broadway.     Distance to city, lack of uniformity of construction, rugged terrain and difficulty of egress and ingress make this a fourth grade area.
